note.p: “beauteous rill” (MS III; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—The River Farg; see Glenfarg (place).
“Streaming through thy mountains high / . . . / hardly seeing the blue sky” (MS III; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—The mountains are the Ochils; see Glenfarg (place).

Queen Victoria, when traveling north in late August 1842 on her first visit to Scotland, commented in her journal on the contrast between the deep wooded enclosure of the Glenfarg ravine compared to the flat and barren landscape that led up to it: “[W]e entered Kinross-shire. Soon after, the country grew prettier, and the hills appeared again, partly wooded. We passed Loch Leven, and saw the castle on the lake from which poor Queen Mary escaped. There the country is rather flat, and the hills are only on one side. . . . Soon after [passing the village of Kinross], the mountains, which are rather barren, began to appear. Then we passed the valley of Glen Farg; the hills are very high on each side, and completely wooded down to the bottom of the valley, where a small stream runs on one side of the road—it is really lovely”.

“[O]n leaving this valley”, Victoria continues, one arrives “in Perthshire”, which is announced by “a beautiful view of Strathearn and Moncrieffe Hill”. This prospect opens when rising out of Glenfarg, exposing the wide valley of the River Earn, which stretches east-northeast to Moncrieffe Hill beyond the village of Bridge of Earn. On the far side of the hill lies the city of Perth.

For the queen’s entourage, the total journey from Kinross-shire required two hours, including the pass through Glenfarg and a change of horses at Bridge of Earn, to arrive at their destination at Dupplin Castle, the residence of the Earl of Kinnoul, which stood a few miles west of Bridge of Earn.The “last part of the road” to the castle, she remarked, entailed “very bad traveling, up and down hill” (Leaves from the Journal of Our Life in the Highlands, 11-12).
“floury mills” (MS III; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Milling was a chief industry in Glenfarg; see Glenfarg (place).
“charlesʼs wain” (MS III; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Charlesʼs Wain is an easily recognizable asterism within the constellation Ursa Major (the Great Bear). See Astronomical Education.

Helen Gill Viljoen (“Viljoen Papers”, box F.X) correctly remarks that Ruskin could have learned the constellations from works by Jeremiah Joyce (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, 2:15–16) or from Thomas Day (Day, Sandford and Merton, 163–64). For Ruskinʼs continuing interest in this constellation, see “Harry and Lucy”, Vol. 2, chap. 1; and “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”

Between lines 24 and 25—The Library Edition incorrectly identifies John James Ruskin as adding the date 9 September 1826. The hand, which is certainly Margaret Ruskinʼs, is identical to that for a similar annotation in MS I.

“[lost]” (Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—In the first publication of this poem, W. G. Collingwood supplied the word lost “in square brackets”, since it “is wanting in the original”. (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:xxv; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:xii). In the sole extant manuscript version, which is a fair copy, there is no evidence of erasure of a word. If a word is missing, it would therefore either have been dropped in fair‐copying or intentionally omitted. Collingwood based his assumption that a word is missing, presumably, on the need of a word ending the second line in the stanza to complete the abab rhyme scheme. He may be correct that the implied rhyme word was “lost” to rhyme with “tost”, referring to the dependency on the pole star to find oneʼs way when lost in the dark. Ruskinʼs probable sources related this practical knowledge about Charlesʼs Wain when teaching the constellations.
